node.text:
Despite making up half of the total workforce, women make up only a quarter of STEM professionals in the United States.  Women represented only about a quarter of computer scientists, and 15% of those in engineering. In certain areas of medicine, it’s not much better. Only 10-15% of actively practicing Cardiologists, (my specialty), are women.
 
But there is a growing group of researchers who are writing a new chapter for women scientists, exposing longstanding discrimination, and leading the way in making science more inclusive. I am beyond honored to partner with @pbs and share Picture a Scientist, one of the most meaningful documentaries about women in STEM. Biologist Nancy Hopkins, chemist Raychelle Burks, and geologist Jane Willenbring share their journey deep into their own experiences in the sciences, ranging from brutal harassment to years of subtle slights. You can stream Picture a Scientist now on the @pbs Video App now!!! #womeninSTEM #womeninmedicine #ilooklikeacardiologist #PictureAScientist #PBS #science #ad

So many people in our country have lost touch with compassion, empathy, and humanity. 💔

node.text:
Had to jump on this trend. I love it SO much.

Med school
Residency
Fellowship
Started a top 10 podcast
Pandemic 
Became a Cardiologist
Invited to speak all over the world about Plant-Based Nutrition
Wear whatever I want/proud of fighting sexism in medicine
Joined a practice I believe in and am so proud of with @angie.sadeghi and @kcklatt 
Invited to committees and editorial boards with my HEROES

Learning so much along the way 

Wouldn’t change a thing...❤️

Forever grateful to the women in medicine who have been pushing through barriers and glass ceilings for years and paved the way for the rest of us. & the men in medicine who fight for equality for women just as hard as we do 🙏

Share your How it started & How it’s going 😊
#womeninmedicine
#ilooklikeacardiologist

node.text:
for inviting me to discuss cardiovascular disease prevention on your podcast with one of the most accomplished cardiologists in history, Dr. Valentin Fuster.

Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D. Is the Physician-in-Chief at The Mount Sinai Hospital, the editor in chief of the Journal of American College of Cardiology (JACC - our top Cardiology Journal), past  President of the American Heart Association, President of the World Heart Federation, member of the Institute of Medicine of the US National Academy of Sciences (where he chairs the committee for the prevention of the global epidemic in heart disease), member of the US National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, and President of the Training Program of the American College of Cardiology, and the only cardiologist to have received the highest awards for research from the four leading international cardiology organizations: the American Heart Association, the American College of Cardiology, the European Society of Cardiology, and the Interamerican Society of Cardiology.

I hope you enjoy this episode where we discuss all things cardiovascular disease prevention, including a few clips here where we discuss how early cardiovascular disease begins, and how important nutrition is in prevention.

To say this was an honor was an understatement. To hear Dr. Fuster call me an expert in nutrition & cardiovascular disease was the greatest compliment of my career as a physician, and I am still pinching myself. I work really hard to do my very best to be the most evidence based, least biased nutrition resource for cardiovascular disease patients, and you’ll hear that in great detail in this episode.

Dr. Fuster goes into great detail about all of his work in health education in children across the world, his research studies that range from Cardiovascular imaging to education and prevention. He details his key recommendations to help prevent heart disease, reduce risk for developing dementia and cancer. 

Check out the full episode here:

https://bit.ly/3jFmlAF

node.text:
Dr. Adeline Fagan, a second year OBGYN resident living in Houston, died early Saturday September 19th, after a couple months-long battle with Covid-19. While she mostly worked delivering babies, Fagan was doing a rotation in the ER treating Covid patients. 

Such a heart breaking story. And an important reminder that we are still in a pandemic. Sending so much love to Adelines family, and to all of my fellow healthcare workers around the world. Adeline is us. 💔 Be safe 🙏

For everyone reading this, please do everything you can to reduce the spread of this virus. Wear a mask. Keep 6 feet from others. Keep washing your hands. The data and science overwhelmingly supports these public health measures to reduce the spread. Please help healthcare providers by reducing the spread of COVID 🙏

node.title: 28 year old OBGYN Dr. Adeline Fagan passed away after a battle with COVID19

node.text: It was an honor to partake in the plant-based versus paleo diets for cardiovascular health debate today! I represented the pro Plant-Based debate. Unfortunately I couldn’t upload the entire debate, but here are a few snippets of my talk! Many thanks to my fellow cardiologists from all around the world for joining today and tuning in, and many many thanks to Dr. Ryan Daly for the invitation! Hope you enjoy :)

node.text:
Our rescue dog has changed our lives! Cooper was a major inspiration for my husband and I going vegan, as he showed us how animals love and feel emotion, fear and pain, the same way we do. We rescued Cooper when he was 3 years old, and today he turns 14 years young! He has an inspiring story, including overcoming becoming paralyzed when he was 11 and learning how to walk again as a senior dog ❤️

But sadly, many loving dogs still need homes. Approximately 3.3 million dogs enter U.S. animal shelters every year, approx 670,000 dogs are euthanized annually because they cannot find homes 😥 #adoptdontshop ❤️and consider if you’re able to, donating to any of these incredible rescue organizations. They have been suffering greatly because of the pandemic but all continue to do amazing work.

@drsfdoxies 
@dachshundrescuela 

humanesociety.org
bestfriends.org
spcai.org
animalaidunlimited.org
Sochidogs.org
ASPCA.org
CWOB.org
susiesseniordogs.com
paws.org.ph
Tacn.org
Pets without Parents

And please share your favorite rescue organizations below!🙏❤️👇

node.title: A little story about why rescue dogs are amazing ❤️

node.text: It’s hard to articulate what it’s been like being a physician during COVID19. I can understand that for people outside of healthcare, for those who have not lost a loved one to COVID, this has probably been a confusing time, where your life has been upended by an invisible enemy.  Shutdowns happened. People have lost their jobs. The economy is struggling. No one is minimizing that at all. It’s HORRIBLE. But so are the 100,000 American lives lost. This is ALL SO complicated. In a time where we need unity, there has been so much division. We live in a time where we need empathy and compassion the most.  Please take just 5 minutes to watch this beautifully articulated piece about being a doctor on the front lines during COVID19 by Dr. Craig Spencer. @craig_a_spencer is the Director of Global Health in Emergency Medicine at New York-Presbyterian/Columbia University Medical Center. He’s a NYC ER doctor fighting COVID, he’s fought on the front lines of Ebola and survived. Hear his story... ❤️🙏

node.text:
It’s been a while since I stirred the pot on Instagram… I’ve been busy being a cardiologist taking care of real patients, so I haven’t had as much time to discuss the anti-science nonsense that still persists. Anti-science, spread by many people who are NOT taking care of real patients every day. People who have never stepped foot in a COVID ICU. People who have never called a patients family to tell them their loved one has died from this virus.

But I’m here to remind you that vaccines work. And science is real. And sometimes I just have to be snarky because there isn’t much left to say about how ridiculous the persistent misinformation is.

Vaccines are our way out of this pandemic. Hard stop.

As a medical student, internal medicine resident, and cardiology fellow, I literally “grew up” reading guidelines, randomized controlled trials, pivotal groundbreaking research papers - written by the Cardiology legends in this picture. I can of think endless times during training I attended SCCT, AHA, ACC, and watched so many of these leading cardiologists present groundbreaking clinical trials, or practice changing guidelines. So needless to say, it’s  an incredible honor in my first year as an attending cardiologist to be invited to speak about preventive cardiology along side these literal cardiology legends this weekend 😊

Join us for the SCCT Cardiovascular Disease Prevention Symposium taking place on Aug 14😊

Thank you SCCT for the opportunity again this year! I cannot wait to attend every single talk & learn from these phenomenal leaders in cardiology!

Registration is open here:

https://scct.org/page/2021PrevSymp

Prevention is my passion. And I am so thankful to all of the leaders in cardiology that have continued to provide me with support, mentoring, and endless opportunity to grow, so that I can share my passion for preventive cardiology, evidence based nutrition, and help as many patients as possible❤️🙏

node.text:
COVID, myocarditis, and heart block.

If you haven’t been vaccinated yet, or if someone you love hasn’t - please consider that COVID sequelae can impact even those who are young and healthy.

38 y/o patient presented with fatigue, 7 weeks s/p COVID +. (Patient was not vaccinated- this was before it was available)
This patient has no past medical history. He experienced a mild case of COVID 7 weeks prior, with some sniffles. Over the last 7 weeks he began to feel more fatigued. He experienced some shortness of breath.

12 lead EKG shows: P waves marked by red arrows. Sinus rhythm, 3:1 AV conduction, RBBB QRS. Unclear if the conducted PR interval is short or long (navy arrow options) - likely the longer one. A PVC marked by asterisk conceals retrograde into conduction system & delays next conducted QRS. 

Heart block can occur from myocarditis, which can happen with different viral infections, including COVID. 

In heart block, the heart's electrical impulses are partially or completely blocked as they attempt to travel from the atrial chambers of the heart to the ventricular chambers. Because these electrical impulses let the heart know when it is supposed to beat, if heart block is severe enough it may slow the heart rate to dangerously low levels.

The patient’s heart block required dual chamber pacemaker placement. With two leads, this device connects to both chambers on the right side of the heart, the right atrium and the right ventricle. This helps to regulate the pace of contractions of both chambers, helps the two chambers work together, contracting & relaxing in the proper rhythm. The contractions allow blood to flow properly from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

The underlying cause was most likely COVID myocarditis, patient will be undergoing cardiac MRI.

Thanks to my colleague & friend, expert electrophysiologist Dr Josh Cooper, for his input on this case.

When we focus on the death rate of COVID, and ignore sequelae like this - we do a great disservice by minimizing the massive impact COVID has on the lives of many people - even those who are young & healthy.

Getting vaccinated is the best way to protect yourself 🙏❤️ #vaccineswork

node.text:
MEDbikini — it’s been one year since women physicians, nurses, NPs/PAs, healthcare professionals everywhere united and got the infamous sexist peer reviewed paper retracted from the Journal of Vascular Surgery which said female physicians wearing bikinis on social media is unprofessional.

In the ridiculous article—  the authors sought out to determine how many vascular surgeons had participated in what they state is “inappropriate social media behavior”, which they defined as photos in BIKINIS - but ?? NOT men in bathing suits.  Other topics considered “inappropriate” were Halloween costumes, gun control and politics.  The “study” was written by 3 men who created fake social media accounts to spy on applicants. Unreal.

I’ve violated all of these “rules.” And I am so proud of the cardiologist I am today❤️

Women in medicine can wear a bikini, a dress, or we can wear scrubs. This does not change how good we are at taking care of patients. We can wear whatever we want on our free time, and still save your life.

Proud of all of the women in medicine who fight daily for gender equality in our field - whether it’s the gender pay gap, representation in your specialty, fighting for respect, or fighting for your female patients to be seen and heard. I’m with you❤️🙌

If you post a #medbikini pic this weekend please tag me so I can hype you up in my stories 👙😍

I will be posting your bikini photos all weekend in my stories as patriarchy protest 💀🔪

And a reminder to all women in medicine… we really can do/be anything we put our minds to. A n y t h i n g .

node.text:
Beyond honored to work with some incredible people at @who to help fight online medical misinformation.

It’s everywhere we look. 

Misinformation about vaccines. Guideline directed medical therapy. Climate change. The food we eat. 

It’s pervasive in the wellness space and alternative medicine. 

I’m so thankful that so many physicians, healthcare providers & scientists are standing up against misinformation - and making intellectual honesty the trend that needs to last forever.

Excited, humbled, and honored to collaborate with the incredible people at @who to change our world for the better❤️

Some tips for healthcare providers and scientific communicators on how we can limit the spread of misinformation. (Thanks @amermedicalassn )

1. Limit dissemination. Medical journals are not the only agents responsible for preventing bad information from taking root in public discourse. Physicians & HCP also can identify the purveyors of misinformation, while regulators and social media executives can limit the extent to which these sources can get their messages out. Editors across traditional and new media, meanwhile, can help by not legitimizing falsehoods in the name of balanced reporting.

2. Create immunity through science literacy. The work of medical journals can be complemented by primary and secondary school educators’ teaching students the scientific method—including why and how it works—as well as critical-thinking skills. Even on social media we can work to ensure scientific literacy in common cognitive errors and logical fallacies regarding qualitative and quantitative data.

3. Inoculate and educate. Physicians, faculty, HCP, and health care organizations, along with public health agencies and communications experts, can all promote a general understanding of medical science and use their media outlets to lay bare common misconceptions.

4. Debunk myths and discredit purveyors. Here too, the larger journalism community, health professionals and medical researchers can provide direct rebuttals and cite the provenance of misinformation, revealing purveyors’ credentials, or lack thereof, and pulling back the curtain on conflicts of interest.

node.text:
Sunglasses ✔️
Hat ✔️
SPF 100 re applied every 90 minutes✔️

Living in California the struggle trying not to get tan is REAL. I surf every day, run outside, bike outside, like, I am working out year round outside every day. I had to call in the experts for advice...
 
Thank goodness for my fave Derms of IG who continue to educate me on all things sunscreen!!
 
Here are some of my fave sunscreen facts by my fave derm ever @ranellamd
-UV light is a Class I carcinogen and the proper and regular use of sunscreen and sun protection are imperative (including protective clothing when possible! Hi hat and sunglasses you are my best friends)
-SPF has nothing to do with how long sunscreen will last. Just because you are wearing SPF 100, it will still start to wear off between 90-120 minutes. We must reapply!
-SPF number speaks ONLY about protection from UVB rays, and says NOTHING about protection from longer wavelength UVA rays, which are largely responsible for photoaged skin. Make sure your sunscreen protects for both!
-Reapplying sunscreen is insanely important. Sunscreen actives can break down with light exposure + easily sweat/wiped off.
-Using sunscreen properly means approx: 1 tsp face/neck, 1 tsp each arm, 1 tsp each leg, 1 tsp abdomen chest, 1 tsp back.
-Clouds do NOT block UV rays
-Did you know that even if you’re working from home, you may need sunscreen. The vast majority of sun exposure incidental/short exposures add up to cumulative damage, and UVA penetrates glass.
-SPF in your make up is not enough protection
-Tan is skin’s response to UV injury 😥 and like sunburn, presence of tan shows damage ALREADY done.

Happy weekend y’all! Sunscreen up!
👯‍♀️ with @drpurviparwani

node.text:
To all healthcare providers out there - this is your reminder to listen to women.
To the women out there reading this - no one knows your body the way you do- and no one is a better advocate for your health than you. We will work to change this every day of our careers until the physical symptoms women experience are evaluated and taken seriously across the board. If you don’t feel heard - find a new physician who gives you the compassionate care you deserve 🙏

Shoutout to the ultimate legend of women’s heart health who I learn from daily - @drmarthagulati

(CCTA = coronary CT angiography, a CT of the coronary arteries; 3VD = triple vessel coronary artery disease)

node.text:
The EAT-Lancet Commission @eatfoundation is one of the most incredible, forward thinking, & comprehensive entities in nutrition, comprised of nutrition experts like Walter Willett, as well as Environmental Scientists, Public Health & Policy Leaders. 
 
According to the EAT-Lancet Commission:
 
The food we eat, the ways we produce it & the amounts wasted or lost have major impacts on human health and environmental sustainability.
 
A diet that includes more plant-based foods & fewer animal source foods is healthy, sustainable, and good for both people and planet. It is not a question of all or nothing, but rather small changes for a large and positive impact.
 
Foods sourced from animals, especially red meat, have relatively high environmental footprints per serving compared to other food groups. This has an impact on greenhouse gas emissions, land use and biodiversity loss. This is particularly the case for animal source foods from grain fed livestock.
 
What is or is not consumed are both major drivers of malnutrition in various forms. Globally, over 820 million people continue to go hungry every day.
 
In parallel, today, over 2 billion adults are overweight and obese, and diet-related noncommunicable diseases including diabetes, cancer and heart diseases are among the leading causes of global deaths.
 
Good food can be a powerful driver of change: The EAT-Lancet Commission outlines a planetary health diet, which is flexible and recommends intake levels of various food groups that can be adapted to local geography, culinary traditions and personal preferences.
 
Globally, the planetary health diet favors increasing the consumption of a variety of fruits, vegetables, nuts and legumes, and if preferred, small portions of meat and dairy. In parts of the world, this diet involves increasing the access to certain food groups while in other areas, the diet requires a significant reduction in the overconsumption of unhealthier foods.
 
Shifting from to the planetary health diet can prevent 11 million premature adult deaths per year and drive the transition toward a sustainable global food system by 2050 that ensures healthy food for all within planetary boundaries.
